Early Access Review
								Disclaimer: Kickstarter backertl;dr: Consider buying if you're a Wipeout fan, keep a close eye on it if you what you see looks interesting. Not remotely enough content for most buyers.The following is based on the Early Access launch version of the game.From some of the original Wipeout developers comes an extremely bare-bones but promising taste of a new AG racing game. At launch there is a single track, one craft, two modes, two weapons and three or so music tracks. Although this is in an early alpha state, the core mechanics are surprisingly satisfying. Compared to Wipeout, the handling is much heavier, collisions are much more punishing, and boosts are more rewarding. Accelerating into turns is not a viable strategy. To my delight, they managed to capture the awesome feeling of gliding as if on auto-pilot when completing three or four tricky turns from Wipeout.Even as someone with experience in this type of game, placing first in the race took nearly an hour. Collision damage makes it very likely that you'll die in your first attempt. Learning the track and placement of boost pads seems essential to winning. Currently there is one weapon in the game, and it's tricky to learn to use (hold the fire button until the missile locks on, then release). Overall, there is an hour of satisfying content here, obviously not yet enough to justify a €28 price tag.As for performance and ease of use, this game is very limited as you can imagine. The menus are not responsive, there's very little in terms of an options menu, but it does feature borderless windowed mode which came at a cost of around 10fps. On my hardware (GTX770, i5-4690k factory settings) I could maintain above 60fps in fullscreen mode on the highest preset. Sound effects don't appear to be implemented, though the music will be appealing if you enjoyed the soundtrack of the Wipeout games. The visuals are great, though obviously could use polish, and the track design seems solid for the first track.Personally, I'm very much looking forward to seeing where this game goes and will update this review throughout development. I'm not a big fan of racing, but I always liked the Wipeout games for their arcadey gameplay and split second handling combined with high fidelity visuals. Having played almost every entry to the series, I was disappointed to hear that Studio Liverpool was shutting down, and I'm glad that Wipeout is getting a spiritual successor in the hands of what appear to be capable developers in the form of Formula Fusion.

								Edit: There's an update on the 24th of December and there's several changes on the games. There's 2 tracks now. Day and night variations. No reverse. You can't ride on the rails to go faster now UI has changed quite a bit. Gone are the minimalistic UI to a more convinient one. There's also added a pitch to go up and downThe only promise they take is that they will release this game as full on August 2016.Original review.Formula Fusion is a futuristic racing game made by R8 Games partnering with Designers Republic. The game at launched in Kickstarter and Steam with the equivalent buzz of Yooka Laylee. Billed in many gaming journalism websites as a “spiritual successor made by former Studio Liverpool developers”, sleek looking graphics, the intent to ride on the E-Sports bandwagon and delivering high speed antigravity racing game akin to the “agile, complex and nimble” WipEout and not the “straight speed, no turning required” F-Zero. They say in Kickstarter that the initial £35,000 KS target was to allow them to create the “‘base game’, which will feature eight tracks created by the WipEout 3 track team and an early-access version featuring one fully developed track”. They actually doubled the goal to £79,656 and in 3 Aug, 2015, they launched this game to Steam.Like any alpha, there are lots of bugs that has yet to be solved and content that is lacking at launch. You can wall ride your craft without care about the hull integrity without getting penalised by slowing the craft down. The UI is minimalistic; the bad kind of minimalism which you need to squint down the screen (not up!) to see the important information like the amount of weapons tokens to deploy your weapon, the time of your lap as well as the energy level that you’re in. The replay value are also lacking. There are currently three tracks to choose from, all of which are reverse or reskins of one another. The 3 additional “QA tracks” exclusive to “Test Pilots” were textured in bare bones grey. One of the tracks struck me as amateurish and so basic that I personally doubt it's been made from some AAA developers like Studio Liverpool. The craft design were nice but currently all the teams selection are cosmetic and doesn’t affect the stats of the craft.The weapons selection? Two. Just two different selections of weapons. One is a hold-space-for-three-seconds-to-fire rocket and the other is the fire and forget “force wall” in WipEout 3.This would have been ok if the game is updated in a consistent time with a solid roadmap. Maybe monthly? Bi-monthly perhaps?Nope! The last update of this game was in 25th August 2015. Even when they secured new investment on the 5th of November, there’s no update from the time this review was posted. There are no guaranteed dates for the next update.All of this while some of the development staff and 2 community managers (one of which I will vouch on being extremely supportive) were laid off as their contract ended.Formula Fusion itself is nice, shiny and cool to show off your friends your GTX 980’s capabilities but from the content, the update schedule and stability as a company, it’s plainly not worth your $20.

								(Review based on v0.0.4)First of all, some background. I've been playing the WipEout games since I discovered the third and went back to play 2097 and 64 and Wip3out Special Edition. I played a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of Pure and HD/Fury. A bit of Pulse. I have Fusion but didn't liked it too much. Haven't played 2048 much since I don't have a Vita. So, moving on...The content is minimal (one ship, one track, two weapons, two music tracks, prototyped menus) so don't be buying this expecting anything near a complete, satisfactory experience, not even in the user interface. Buy this in order to support the developers so they can add content and fulfill their vision.What you get though, is a pretty promising skeleton of a game. The sole ship is beautifully rendered and the track looks nice (although I hope the floor gets higher resolution textures later on). The handling is based off 2097's. I'm not so sure about that since I liked the "floaty" handling of 3, Pure, Pulse and HD/Fury, it was nice to have some altitude control. This doesn't apply here, ship's altitude is fixed at the same height always. Not a bad feature, mind you, I guess I liked it when it felt a bit like an airplane and not a hovercraft ala F-Zero. The handling has a learning curve, specially if you're used to Wipeout HD, but it becomes second nature.I liked the boost of the speed pad. The camera struggles to keep up with the ship for a fraction of a second when you get a boost, which enhances the feeling of speed greately. I hope that in future versions they make the camera feel more like a real floating object so this motion becomes more natural.NO MORE RANDOM WEAPONS, my God, how am I glad of this and I hope it's not just a placeholder feature. This was what was holding Wipeout back. Didn't you hate when you were last place and you got the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed mines? Or when you got the quake while at the head of the pack? Sure, 2048 lets you distinguish between offensive and defensive pickups, but these subsets were still random. No more random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here, it seems. If you want to see how much this impacts this kind of combat racing games, go play Blur on hard (an awesome and underrated game, by the way). That one opened my eyes. Leave the random nonsense ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to Mario Kart.TL;DR: I didn't even cared to look at the feature list at this stage of development, I'm a WipEout fan and I'm glad to throw these developers some money so they keep WipEout's spirit alive. Early Access Review
								*03/14/2017 UpdateGave the game another shot after a few months and the controls are still horrid. No matter what I did to try and compensate...nada. Hitting the walls should not be a feature. I've been playing WipeOut since the original on PS1. When there wasn't analog controls and gamers had to drive with the Dpad. So I'm not unfamiliar with trial and error and "getting used to" a bad setup. But it's 2017, not 1996. The controls are too loose making it hard to keep a racing line and it's made worse because some tracks have really narrow sections that you hit at high speed. How the hell are we supposed to navigate those with these controls? WipeOut was a source of pride for many fans because of the developed ability to race at high speeds on extreme tracks and still achieve perfect laps. I have not been able to get ONE perfect lap since I've started playing Formula Fusion. I played WipeOut 2048 yesterday after not playing it for a few months and got 4 in the first 3 races. That's the barometer. If no one can get a perfect lap at the highest speeds in the easier track in Formula Fusion, then the controls are trash and need to be updated. *08/28/2016 Update. I just spend a couple of hours with the latest update. Formula Fusion is better than it was prior to the update, but I still can't recommend it for many of the same reasons listed below. The controls are the biggest problem. I challenge anyone to get a perfect lap with a record setting time on Mannahatta or Atlas or any track for that matter. Niagara is the only track that gives wide enough track width to get a feel of what Formula Fusion could be but the controls cause problems even there. Why the fetish for insanely narrow tracks at high speed with controls that make it impossible to navigate without hitting the walls? I even saw the computer zig zagging on straights as if the AI was trying to come to grips with the car. I couldn't even play this in first person (how I normally like to play) because the controls are unwieldy causing the same zig zagging motion trying to keep straight. I went back last night into this morning and played WipeOut HD, WipeOut Pulse and WipeOut 2048...on VITA no less and it's not just me. I can still play those games and do extremely well. So yeah, is Formula Fusion better than it was? Sure. But instead of being godawful, it's just bad now. Graphics are still excellent, the game runs well as I was able to run it in 1080p and even 3000x2000 without any issues. The art direction is there. But the music still sucks and the track design doesn't live up to the WipeOut series Formula Fusion wants to be. Even the old PSP versions are better. The potential is still there but at this point it's going to take a Herculean effort for Formula Fusion to be a WipeOut alternative. As I mentioned, I challenge anyone to race a perfect lap with a good time or high placement in a race on any track in this game. I could do this on many tracks in the WipeOut games I mentioned including Sebenco Climb, Sol 2 and UberMall. I have never been able to do this on any track thus far in Formula Fusion.*Original ReviewI can not recommend this game at this stage. Yes, the graphics are good but  the controls...OMG the controls. The controls ultimately killed the experience for me, made worse by bad track design and terrible music. The videos looked so promising.... The physics of the cars are so floaty that it's far too easy to oversteer and understeer resulting in a zig zag motion as you fight to control the car, even on straights. Mind you, I'm no rookie to futuristic racers. I've been a WipeOut fan since the original in 1995. I've been a F-Zero fan since it's debut in the early 90s. I even earned the Platinum Trophy in WipeOut 2048 even though it is capped at 30 frames per second, the controls are a bit weird and the online is terrible. If members of the now defunct Studio Liverpool aka Psygnosis from the Amiga glory days, are responsible for Formula Fusion, then why are the controls so bad even at this stage? Why are other great concepts from WipeOut not present here? A tell tale sign of bad controls are in the dismal New York track. One car width lanes at high speed but you absolutely can not avoid hitting walls every 3 seconds. Forget about actually competing with the other cars or getting a perfect lap.  I've tried different controller configurations, adjusted the analog stick, used gyroscope steering, used touchpad steering....no joy. Atlas (which looks great and reminds me of Sol in WipeOut) starts off laughably bad. A really cool loop and tunnel with speed pads that launch you forward but as soon as you exit the tunnel, there's a sharp turn with a blue turn barrier on the left. If you don't brake and lead into the turn your car rides up the side of the barrier and goes off the track. With the controls being so bad, trying to actually navigate that break down and lead in for the turn becomes a clumsy practice in frustration. That's the word that describes playing Formula Fusion. Clumsy. Very pretty, but clumsy.Here's the thing though. The potential is there. As I mentioned, the graphics are good. The basic presentation is good and so much like WipeOut thanks to Designers Republic (good to see them back too). The sense of speed is good. The effects are good. Formula Fusion has the potential to be the WipeOut fans deserve since Sony gave up on it. But it's like death by a thousand cuts at this point. The little problems accompanied by the bad controls lay the title low at this early stage. I have some hope though. I just hope that the developers understand that if they design a track that is impossible to get a perfect lap on while competing with the other cars or so frustrating that it's not fun, then it's obviously a terrible track design that shouldn't be used.Another example, in the original WipeOut, if your car hit a wall even at a slight angle, the car came to a full stop with a loud "thud" of a sound. It totally killed the immersion and flow of the game. Studio Liverpool agreed and in WipeOut XL designed it so that the cars could glide across the wall if you brushed against them at the right angle. You could continue on but took shield damage. Of course, if you're angle was too direct then you did hit the wall and came to stop. THAT'S a awesome concept and compromise that made the game so much more fun to play. But it's not present in Formula Fusion. You can glide...a bit against the walls but it's accompanied by an annoying "thud" sound and with the bad controls...well it's too easy to come to a full stop from fighting to stay in control of the car. It's just so...clumsy. The game doesn't come together like WipeOut 2048, WipeOut HD, WipeOut Fusion or XL. Even the lackluster WipeOut 64 was more fun to play than this.I'll keep Formula Fusion installed for the foreseeable future to see what the next update brings but for anyone looking for a WipeOut fix, you may want to wait for an update or two or try elsewhere. Formula Fusion isn't worth the money...yet.

								I come from the tradition of the old f-zero, then podracer for the n64, then f-zero for the gamecube, and finally fatal inertia for the xbox, as opposed to the majority of people who played wipeout, so I have a different perspective on anti-grav racers than most of the reviewers. That being said, I like this game, it has promise, but here are my impressions.I played the useless tutorial and then two practice races. I lost my first practice race and then I won my second one by literally a minute and a half distance between me and second place. The AI is clearly currently bad. However, some of these four tracks within themselves could use a bit more variety, they felt more like leisurely drives than perhaps what an anti-grav racetrack would be like. The airbrake is worse than useless, it actively slows you down and doesn't help you corner faster. That's an easily fixed problem though, and could help with the "leisurely drive" issue, since you have something to do other than push the stick gently to one side. The graphics are beautiful. My aging laptop has a time keeping up, but I love how the world and racers look. Engine effects could have a bit mor umphff, but that's knitpicky. It does a fairly good job of giving you the impression of speed. Overall though, if you want a game like the ones I cited up there and won't compromise, pass on this, it feels much too caged and repetitive compared to those, and the meager distraction offered by the boost pads won't feel like much compared to dodging trees, rocky rivers, and flying down active volcanoes.If you're a sucker in general for anti-grav (me), then this is a good buy, so I give it a tacit recommendation. From what I could tell, the model for all the factions is more/less the same, but with different paintjobs. I highly believe that will change at a later date.As far as the stuff that doesn't affect game play at all. The menu is pretty simple and easy to navigate (but still has a pretty cool futuristic feel to it though). The music is rippin! I love the music. In a time where it's raining 'early access games', it's easy to forget THAT THEY'RE STILL IN DEVELOPMENT. Some people would be happier than a MF'er to tell you Redout is a better game, and the correct answer to that is; They're two different games in different stages of development. One is mindnumbingly chaotic and one is a little more smooth. Neither is a better game than the other. Remember to enjoy them both. AG Racing is a very niche style and they don't come often. 								The R8 Twitter account asked for reviews. You sure that's a thread you want to be pulling on so soon? OK.In it's current state, I don't think I could recommend Formula Fusion. The community was pretty specific about either the vehicles being too clunky for the tracks, or the tracks being too narrow for the vehicles, yet it took the completion of a further 2 tracks for this complaint to be listened to. How the devs thought the faster speed classes would be able to navigate Trans Atol is a mystery. Trans Atol and Mannahatta will need to be deleted, and Niagara will need some work before I can recommend this game.Tl;drPros-Nice soundtrackVisually interesting tracksCons-Devs need to pay more attentionTracks were not designed with the speed and handling of the vehicles in mind.

Early Access Review
								The best way to summarize this game is by saying "it is alright". It's nowhere near as good as Wipeout HD, but it does fill the very small niche genre that is anti grav racing with another contribution. I wouldn't recommend this game, but it's on the verge of. Currently there's no real fun in playing; most things work - but there's no progression and the racing itself is rather bland. Weapons, despite working, aren't polished. Maps are very narrow - causing you to run into walls even when steering really well. There're also some balancing issues, which cause occasionally colliding with the crash barrier to be more favorable than using brakes. The sounds ingame honestly just poor. The music is uninspiring, but okay(many of the AG racing games are known for an exceptional musical presentation - which FF really just isn't pulling off with it's generic liquid DnB). The playerbase is non existent. The game hasn't seen updates since a while, but most updates are of considerable size. The UI is a bit clunky. The ships physics are near non existent(in contrary to many other AG racers it doesn't feel *at all* like you're floating. The ship feels glued to the track which is very unsatisfying). The good include that the maps look "pretty good" on average(not spectacular like Wipeout HD, but pretty good). The ships look good. There's a strong feeling of high speed and it overall feels pretty futuristic. This however comes at the cost of very poor handling(it feels nothing like you're controlling a craft of any sort) and falls flat on it's face when trying to deliver the adrenaline-rush gameplay the classics had. I'm personally not very fond of the screen shaking and overkill motion blur, but perhaps there's an audience for that.The REAL reason I don't recommend this game is for it's going to be released this year, which means it'll just be a watered down indie attempt at recreating Wipeout HD minus a real progession system. It's "okay" in all respects. You'll need to be a hardcore AG racing fan to get more than 2/3 hours of fun out of this game.

								I remember, with a warm nostalgic glow, when I first came across the gem that was Wipeout XL a very long time ago. It was in a box of games my brother sent me, hand-me-downs that he didn't play anymore or never grew a fondness of. I remember how roughly the racers handled on the tracks, they required real control, it was more like flying than racing, and the frictionless environment would almost let you go faster than you had any business to. There was something about the game too, the environments, to me they seemed realistic but surreal, like something from both the future and the past, and the lights, it was like someone dropped a disco bomb on Tokyo.At the time Wipeout XL came out, graphics accelerator cards were fairly new, and I was always excited to try a game that made use of the new hardware. I couldn't believe the night and day difference between the pixellated oldies and the smooth high res new hotness. It felt like game designers could communicate more to the player through their graphics than they could before, that they could present the world they wanted to present as they wanted to present it. Everything felt very futuristic and authentic and this went a long way towards immersing the player.It's been a long time since I played a wipeout game, I have wipeout pure for the PSP which was okay, but not a modern title that utilized my hardware and just didn't quite ring with me like Wipeout XL, and then I came across Formula Fusion. I was hesitant at first, I've been burned with early access titles, but I saw that they just released a new update and strong was my jones, so I figured I'd pick it up, try it out for a little bit and if I didn't like it, I'd just return it.I installed the game, loaded up the first race, the music hit, the damp uneven track of New York raceway spread out before me, a familiar grin began to spread across my face. This was it, the Wipeout XL of the modern era.

								Having watched this game for months (and as a huge fan of both the wipEout and F-Zero series), I had built up some substantial expectations. Many of them were actually met, which is fantastic. In other areas, Formula Fusion was lacking (which I'm attributing to the Early Access status).The game is beautiful, and the controls are smooth. The machines feel heavy, which adds an element of realism. Another realistic aspect that I'm not quite as fond of is the relatively low speeds. The game is fast-paced, don't get me wrong, but the huge environments and small tracks don't feel like you're rushing through the arena at mach 7, they feel like a speedy Gran Turismo.The small tracks. With how slowly the machines turn, they definitely need to be wider. At this point, there are some pixel-perfect turns in-game, which is a fun challenge in one respect, and a frustrating design flaw in another.My only real complaint, though, is the lack of a local multiplayer. This is a game that would be amazing pulling an all-nighter with friends and pizza. We always play F-Zero X or wipEout, but they're increasingly dated games. This would be a great next-gen addition to the repertoire. Just saying, I'd be more inclined to recommend people get it if it had local multiplayer.Lastly, I'm looking forward to new content. Especially with weapons. This is a great opportunity for some creativity, guys. Even just a homing missile would be an improvement (or maybe there is one, and I've just not found it yet).

Early Access Review
 I received this game for free in return of my unbiased review  Formula Fusion Note: Steam doesnt seem to record game time while offline. I actually spent about 6 hours on this game, prior to review. TL; DR I recommend this game! Navigation/Gameplay The gameplay is solid and fun. The menu navigation was swift and intuitive. The races feel like fast paced roller coasters with loops, twists, and sharp turns. I really liked the upgrade system, as it allows you to spend exactly how much you want in each aspect of your ship. Upgrading has a big impact on your ship, such as how well it handles, how responsive the breaks are, or how defensive/ offensive your ship is. It feels truly rewarding to upgrade your ship. I have one big complaint… or you could consider it a recommendation. R8 games has something unique going on with Formula Fusion, but the multiplayer is either deserted or broken. The multiplayer also seems to be a bit shallow featured. I feel if they fix or populate the multiplayer and make more competitive features and modes, it would add a whole new feel to the game. I think R8 game’s biggest chance with this game is putting multiplayer on the top of their priority. Aside from that, there’s nothing else too bad about the game. The controls are good and responsive as long as you use an Xbox controller (or something similar, I used the NVIDIA Controller). Lastly, the music wasn’t quite my taste… but that’s probably just me. Graphics The graphics are beautiful. The ship models are especially amazing. You can tell the developers really took time on the graphics and models. Each level is colorful and feels different than the last. Sadly, the screen seems to look fuzzy and grainy when going full speed. Other than that, there’s nothing else to complain about as far as visuals are concerned.  Optimization My specs are GTX 960 (4 GB ddr5 VRAM), Athlon 880K (Over-Clocked to 4.2), and 8 GB of DDR3 ram. For reference, I run Star Wars: Battlefront on custom MED/HIGH settings at about 30-33 FPS. I ran the game at “EPIC” settings and got about 25-30 FPS. I didn’t see any FPS/ performance change when adjusting the settings.  Keep in mind there are sparks, thruster flame trails, basic lighting, and some nice shadows. I’ll let you be the judge of how good the optimization is. There is always room for improvement when optimizing a game. Crashes/Bugs  I only had one Bug. When I exited the garage the game froze and everything became fuzzy. Sound continued to play. I was forced to CTRL-ALT-DEL and restart my PC. Other than that, it’s been hassle free. Conclusion In conclusion, the game is worth the $20 dollar price tag as long as R8 games really support it and do regular updates and bug fixes. I really hope they take my advice in expanding the multiplayer features. I feel a competitive multiplayer update would really make Formula Fusion stand out from all the other generic sci-fi racing games. 								As a fan of the WipEout series (WipEout HD + Fury, Pure and Pulse), this game definitely lives up to the ideal successor status. The game rapidly generates itself, it's lore and overall aesthetic world in a somewhat dim future. It is quite clear the aesthetics of the racing teams are bridging a large techno-cultural gap between itself and Formula 1. Not everything appears to be starry, spangled and utopic, however. Some tracks are marvelous city escapades, while others are industrial, gritty and flashy Blade Runner styled backdrops. The use of the Unreal engine really fleshes out the sense of speed; whether you enjoy camera shake or without camera shake, everything feels fast. The feeling of transitioning from low to high speeds is thrilling, which makes cornering all the more impactful. Finally, when one grasps the winding corriders, tunnels and corners of a track, the feeling of basic mastery is rewarding as any anti-gravity racer.

Mannahatta is absolutely astonishing, with it's rain effect and under costruction/hi-tech scenario in which tha track is installed. Atlas Torres concept is almost never treated in actual racing video games, so I suggest you to check some pics of the track to make you understand what I mean. Niagara GP track design is good, but it's a little bit naked of elements surrounding the track. An update is planned the next month for Niagara GP, and I hope for a good revamp of the track.- Ships are separated in classes, which is a good thing for racing and time trial competitions. This choice prevents a single ship to prevail on the other ones, and gives the opportunity to try different competition settings. F4000 is the main ship they're working on actually, and it feels really good to drive. The ship sliding feels natural and fun to play. F3000 is a lot faster than F4000, but it has similiar physics to the last I mentioned, so it feels a little uncomfortable to drive for who has never tried it. Just make some practice, and you'll find out it doesn't feel that bad to drive.- Game's graphics looks amazing for this alpha stage; details for the two available ships and for the tracks themselves are truly curate. Graphic effects are still a bit strange, but for this alpha stage they're pretty good. I couldn't imagine how the game would look in it's complete release.- The actual OST of the game is good to enjoy, I would like to hear something more like this in the future releases. More Drum 'n' Bass, please!- Practice Mode is good for those that don't understand well the physics of the game, making you avoid to touch walls with antigravitational waves that pull you at the center of the track. Give it a try if you just bought the game and you want to get into the game a little.Let's now talk about the game negative aspects.- As of now, there are only two items available, and you could set just one of them available for a race. They still feel weird to use, as they don't slow you down when you get hit by them; you just lose shield. I hope they will add more of them in a Mario Kart way, and that they will be revisited with the full release.- A single boost pad sometimes could give you a double boost out of nothing. A glitch that needs to be fixed soon.- Passing between two near boost pads with the ship could cause you to get a doubled boost. This compromises/randomizes a little time trial competitions, and could be extremely clutch on races when you don't except to get a double boost.- Opponent's AI is still a bit easy to beat. Also, the frame rate drops and then fluctuates between 25-45 fps on tracks like Niagara GP and Atlas Torres when AI is moving. An issue that needs to be fixed soon.I also want to talk about neutral aspects of the game.- The ship's handling feel ok by now, but it's still a bit woody, especially when you're trying to countersteer. But R8 Games is actually working on it, releasing with every patch a refreshed and refined handling system.Even if there are a lot of things to fix for this game, it's still in early access, and to see an huge work like that drives me to think at what the game could look once it's finished, and to tell you to buy the game if you like racing games.Also, there are a lot of features that are coming to the game in the future, like online multiplayer races, endurances, more items and a lot of stuff like that, so the game will have a lot to offer.If you like Antigravity racing games or the Wipeout series, give Formula Fusion a chance, you won't be disappointed once the game will be released.(This game review will be edited until the full release of the game, to match up with early access releases details.)

Early Access Review
								While the game itself is relatively new in terms of EA, and content starved for the moment (1 track , 1 craft with skin variations, 2 game modes), many of the core features that exist in the game are done quite nicely. Mechanics seen in the Wipeout series, such as Air-braking might feel strange at first because of the lack of drift, but after a few sessions you become accustomed to it. Collisions can also be unforgiving  (similar to those in wip3out) where one bump into a wall can cause a massive slowdown, emphasizing the need to remember where speed pads are placed and to optimize your racing line accordingly. Weapons are also included in the game, allowing you to pick from either the offensive missile to lock on and attack opponents in front of you, or a barrier that can be placed down to slow those behind you. Keep in mind that these are weapons you choose to take before the start of a session, so you appear to be limited to a single weapon type during a race. Overall i wasnt expecting too much at the start of EA, so i was a bit pleased to see the game functioning rather nicely (aside from the occasional crash between sessions). If you do decide to jump in and buy the game now, beware of the songs that are currently added. You'll probably go insane hearing them loop endlessly. :D

Early Access Review
								Not perfect just yet, but then it /is/ still in development. Plus sides: decent music so far, especially as of the latest update. The handling is pretty good, though it takes a bit of getting used to. Really, really nice graphically, especially the Niagara GP circuit. You can notice the different teams handling differently (personal fave so far is the team "OK") so there's nice variation. You also get the same sense of adrenaline rush and reward after practice that you get in Wipeout, which I love.Downsides: As mentioned, the controls take a bit of getting used to. At first it's very easy to over-steer, making it feel like drunk driving, but once you get the hang of it, it's not so bad. Could do with being a /little/ less sensitive though IMO. The game also seems to have mixed performance. I can run it smoothly on highest settings, but it seems like every so often the game ♥♥♥♥s itself for a few seconds and lags really hard, and then goes back to normal. Optimisation problems maybe? Turning the graphics/resolution down has not fixed this. Also, the rockets seem really overpowered as a weapon. If you get hit by one when your shields are at 3/4 full or less, it seems like you just die instantly, it's ridiculous. Unless I'm just really unlucky.Problems aside though this has serious potential and I'd really love to see it succeed. It's nice how the devs listen to feedback from the fans too (if you're reading this, hi, R8!). Might be a bit pricey for the average gamer due to its Early Access status, but if you're a racing game or especially a Wipeout aficionado, it;s well worth the buy.

								Having written a fairly negative review in March, here are my impressions as of May 2016 :I'm still not sure whether to recommend this or not. The game still severely lacks content, with only two crafts (only one being usable in races) and three tracks. Considering that there is a greyed-out "garage" section on the main menu, I suppose that more content is coming.Since the last version however, many of the problems related to the physics have been addressed. The game now feels way more consistent.The crafts still handle a bit counter-intuitively, but it now feels like it's by design, and that I just need to "git gud" in order to win some races. I still tend to finish most of the races dead last, unless I go for "practice mode", which seems to make things easier. There should be some way to control the difficulty level.As far as graphics go, the game looks nice and shiny. The tracks look really nice, with fairly high resolution textures on the materials, detailed reflections and really convincing (physically-based?) lighting. However, this comes at the price of performance. The game is very taxing on hardware, especially on the Mannahatta track. I get 40~50 FPS on that track at 1080p, Epic details (i5 3750k @ 4 GHz,  16 Gb RAM, GTX 980).Sound effects are a bit lacking, and the music is kind of bland for the most part.It is still early days for that game. It does however show some potential. Hold your purchase if you want to have a ton of fun right now, or bite the bullet if you want to help the developers deliver what could be a decent spiritual successor to Wipeout.Original review :As of March 2016, the game is barely playable. The developers clearly aim to make a game that play like the Wipeout series, however the crafts playable in this version handle very poorly. Touching a wall stops the craft dead on by wedging it against the wall. Crafts sometimes clip into the ground. The controls feel a bit laggy. Also performance is all over the place, with the game feeling very choppy despite fairly high frame-rate figures.Content-wise, not much of it has been implemented yet, although the two crafts and three tracks in the current version all  look nice and shiny.Formula Fusion has a lot of potential, but as of yet the slightly broken handling makes it no fun, especially after playing quite a bit of Fast Racing Neo.

								The devs have reappeared a little and added a new patch. However, I feel the last few patches have been taking steps in the wrong direction and a lot of the decisions being made on all aspects seem to tarnish the gameplay. Another issue is that no settings are ever written into memory correctly it seems; start a new race and your graphics settings will have changed. Go back from your current race settings and they will be reverted to their original state and plenty of other adverse behaviour. I wouldn't have minded all this mess if it wasn't on early access for as long as it has been.Regarding the physics and feel of the ships, it feels like none of them fit the track design. They either handle incredibly well with no need for using air brakes or other features or fly extremely fast, but is then restricted by the sharp turns and motion blur. I so miss some of the early patches when the ship felt like it had some weight, that you had to consider the upcoming turn and position well. Is there really a benefit to air brakes right now? Right now I just don't have fun and it makes me sad since I love these types of games.
